title: 110_hr7278
content: The "Retirement Fairness and Emergency Relief Act of 2008" suspends the required beginning date for distributions from defined contribution plans. The "Retirement Fairness and Emergency Relief Act of 2008" suspends the application of section 401(a)(9) of the Internal Revenue Code for defined contribution plans during the period from January 1, 2008, to December 31, 2009. The required beginning date for distributions is extended to the later of the calendar year specified in the Code or calendar year 2010, and the suspension period is not counted for time limitations. During the suspension period under the "Retirement Fairness and Emergency Relief Act of 2008," certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code apply to defined contribution plans and eligible deferred compensation plans. Failure to make a payment from a qualified retirement plan during this period will not be treated as a modification for tax purposes. Section 72(t)(2)(A)(iv) of the Internal Revenue Code applies to plan amendments, stating that any plan or annuity contract must be operated according to its terms during a specified period. This section also applies to any amendments made before the end of the first plan year starting on or after January 1, 2009. Section 72(t)(2)(A)(iv) of the Internal Revenue Code requires that any plan or annuity contract must be operated according to its terms during a specified period. This provision does not apply to any amendment unless the plan or contract is operated as if the amendment were in effect and applies retroactively for the period specified. The section takes effect on the date of the enactment of the Act. Individuals can recontribute distributions received between January 1, 2008, and the enactment date to an eligible retirement plan before the suspension period ends. The section allows individuals to recontribute distributions received between January 1, 2008, and the enactment date to an eligible retirement plan before the suspension period ends. Contributions made to eligible retirement plans other than IRAs are treated as eligible rollover distributions under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The section allows individuals to recontribute distributions received between January 1, 2008, and the enactment date to an eligible retirement plan before the suspension period ends. Contributions made to eligible retirement plans other than IRAs are treated as eligible rollover distributions under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Repayments for distributions from IRAs are treated as direct trustee to trustee transfers within 60 days. SEC. 3. WAIVER OF 10 PERCENT PENALTY ON WITHDRAWALS FROM QUALIFIED RETIREMENT PLANS DURING 2008 AND 2009 FOR FINANCIAL HARDSHIP. The waiver of the 10 percent penalty on withdrawals from qualified retirement plans during 2008 and 2009 for financial hardship exempts qualified financial hardship distributions from additional tax under the Internal Revenue Code. Qualified foreclosure distributions refer to payments received between December 31, 2007, and January 1, 2010, due to financial hardship. The Secretary of the Treasury can determine financial hardship for individuals. The maximum amount for qualified financial hardship distributions in a taxable year is $15,000. Recipients can repay the distributed amount within 5 years to an eligible retirement plan. The IRS allows rollover contributions from eligible retirement plans for qualified financial hardship distributions. Repayments of distributions from eligible retirement plans other than IRAs are treated as eligible rollovers under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The IRS allows rollover contributions from eligible retirement plans for qualified financial hardship distributions, including direct trustee to trustee transfers within 60 days. Repayments for distributions from IRAs are treated as eligible rollovers under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Qualified financial hardship distributions are exempt from trustee to trustee transfer and withholding rules under sections 401(a)(31), 402(f), and 3405 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. These distributions are treated as meeting plan distribution requirements. The amendments made by this section shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act, and distribution shall be treated as meeting specific requirements of the Internal Revenue Code.
